tutorial.title: Class and ID selectors
tutorial.descriptionContent: Discover how to add colors, font styles, and formatting to make beautiful webpages with CSS.

lessons.title: Applied to tags
lessons.interactiveContent: If there are multiple elements of the same kind on a webpage, selectors like h1, h2, or p change all of these elements.

lessons.title: Class attribute
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we want to select one or more elements, we can set a class attribute for the exact elements we want to change.

In the stylesheet, we can set a new class rule with a . followed by the name of the class. Like here with .gray-element.

Make sure to pick .gray-element.

lessons.title: Class attribute
lessons.interactiveContent:
The rules for the class will apply to all elements that have that class attribute in the html file.

Classes aren't unique, so we can set the same class for multiple elements. Like here for example, with class = "gray-element".

Make sure to pick class, followed by =, and finally "gray-element".

lessons.title: Using class
lessons.interactiveContent:
To set a class as a selector in CSS, add a period followed by the class name. In this case, it's .gray-element.

Make sure to pick ., followed by gray-element.

lessons.title: Question 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we apply a style to one or more, but not all elements on a webpage?

With the class selector With the tag selector

With the class selector .

lessons.title: Question 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with this code?

The selector is missingThe property and value are missing

The selector is missing.

lessons.title: Question 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
What forms a rule?

A selector and its properties form a CSS ruleOnly properties and values form a CSS rule

A selector and its properties form a CSS rule.

lessons.title: Question 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with this rule?

The color property doesn't have a valueThe selector starts with a .

The color property doesn't have a value.

lessons.title: class
lessons.interactiveContent:
In the HTML, add a class to the first h2 element.

Make sure to pick class, followed by =, and finally "suits".

lessons.title: class
lessons.interactiveContent:
Apply a background color to the h2 elements with the "suits" class by creating a class rule.

Make sure to pick . followed by suits and then {, background-color: teal;, }.

lessons.title: class - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
Back to the HTML, add a new class to the second h2 element by coding class="ties".

Make sure to type class="ties".

executableContent.instructions: Use AI to create a rule that sets a background color for elements of the `.ties` class.

lessons.title: Styling groups of elements
lessons.interactiveContent:
We've seen how we can use HTML tags and CSS classes to change the styles of groups of elements.

Include the button tag selector to make all buttons lightblue and the text class selector to make the texts italic.

Make sure to pick button, followed by .text.

lessons.title: Selecting one element
lessons.interactiveContent:
If we want to style a specific element, we can include an id selector. Here, we only want to select the button with the capital letter.

First, we need to identify the element in the html. To set an ID attribute, type id="".

Make sure to pick id, followed by =, and finally "".

lessons.title: Unique IDs
lessons.interactiveContent:
After the = sign, set the value of the id, "capital-letter" in this case.

ID values should be unique within the HTML document. So, we must not include a second id attribute with the same value.

Make sure to pick id, followed by =, and finally "capital-letter".

lessons.title: Using the selector
lessons.interactiveContent:
Now that we have included the id in the HTML element, we are ready to use the id selector for our styles.

To select the element by its id, we type # followed by the name of the id, like capital-letter here.

Make sure to pick #, followed by capital-letter.

lessons.title: Using the selector - Copy
lessons.interactiveContent:
IDs will help us with JavaScript and we shouldn't overuse them for styling. However, we can apply styles as usual with the id selector.

Include the full rule for the #capital-letter id.

Make sure to pick #capital-letter {, followed by color: blue;, and finally }.

lessons.title: Question 1
lessons.interactiveContent:
What are IDs for?

IDs identify HTML unique elementsIDs style groups of elements

IDs identify HTML unique elements.

lessons.title: Question 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we set an ID attribute in the html file?

By typing id in the opening tagBy typing id between the opening and closing tags

By typing id in the opening tag.

lessons.title: Question 3
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we use an ID selector in a stylesheet?

#id-name.id-name

Make sure to pick #id-name.

lessons.title: Question 4
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why do we say IDs are unique?

Because two elements must not have the same IDBecause they group elements

Because two elements must not have the same ID.

lessons.title: id selector
lessons.interactiveContent:
Create an ID selector that only styles elements with a #football ID.

Make sure to pick # followed by football and then {, color: red;, }.

lessons.title: id selector
lessons.interactiveContent:
Assign a football ID to the first paragraph by adding id="football" to the opening tag.

Make sure to type id="football".

executableContent.instructions:
Let's do the same for the rest of the sports. We've already added the IDs to the HTML. Your task is to create one selector for each sport in the CSS file. Inside each selector, set any color you like.

Feel free to use AI to help you out.

files.name: index.html
files.content:
My favorite sports

Football

Basketball

Tennis
